Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Justin Acheson of University of Wisconsin Madison to conduct a research project in Biology during the summer of 2013 at The University of Tokyo in Tokyo, Japan. The project title is "Understanding the Effects of Redox State in Protein-Protein Electron-Transfer Complexes." The host scientist is Prof. Hideaki Nojiri.

Electron transfer plays an essential role in the cellular processes of all living organisms, and in most cases must be achieved by transient protein-protein interactions. In order to achieve efficient transfer, while deterring spurious and possibly detrimental interactions, organisms have evolved interacting partners to share complimentary surfaces as well as redox affinity. This project probes how the binding affinities are changed as a result of redox state and reduction in the multi-component enzyme system carbazole 1, 9a-dioxygenase, a member of an important class of enzymes with potential for bioremediation.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, a relationship will be established between labs that work to answer similar questions, and lead to further collaborations. By sharing this experience, the Fellow will encourage students and colleagues to take opportunities to study abroad, and develop relationships with international scientists that can greatly flourish throughout their careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. Microorganisms exist in dynamic environments that require adaptation to survive amongst their neighbors, limited resources, and introduction of compounds due to industrial development. Many of these organisms have evolved versatile systems including bacterial multi-component monooxygenases (BMM) that allow them to utilize extremely toxic and recalcitrant compounds metabolically, or the ability to degrade the toxicity of the compounds. These taxing chemical reactions often require a complex of protein enzymes to achieve lateral transfer of electrons and/or active site attenuation to achieve catalysis. This requires the interacting proteins to be fine tuned to recognize each other without causing spurious interactions with other entities that could waste precious energy or produce detrimental products. Understanding the mechanisms underpinning these exquisite interactions may shed light on how multi-protein systems have evolved, how to predict binding partners, or how to exploit protein surface topologies to create a functional binary pair. The latter having application in antibody protein engineering.

            Toluene 4-monoxygenase is a BMM that allows Pseudomonas mendocina to grow on toluene as its sole carbon source. The hydroxylase, where catalysis occurs, must interact with both an electron-transfer partner, and an effector protein that binds to attenuate the reaction. To further complicate matters, these two small proteins have highly different surface topologies but must bind to the same region on the hydroxylase at different times to progress the catalytic cycle. To understand the binding energies involved in the interactions isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC) was used. The initial results of the experiments were quite intriguing, however served to produce more questions, than answers. In doing so, a collaboration was established to further design new experiments to be carried out after leaving Japan.

 

 

Broader Impacts. The EAPSI program through the NSF is an invaluable experience for young researchers. The ability to participate in an international setting and to forge real, lasting scientific collaborations was not something I thought possible before learning about the fellowship. Researching in Japan allowed me to understand how scientists in other nations tackle similar problems. Many scientific breakthroughs are a result of an outside view or a change in the way one approaches a problem. By interacting with foreign researchers, one if forced to leave their comfort zone and engage differently, often leading to a break from possible research stagnation.

Conducting research in Japan also affords time to explore its rich history. The generous fellowship encourages cultural immersion that creates a lasting experience, allowing my Japanese counterparts and myself to truly engage with one another inside and outside of the laboratory.

Since returning from Japan I have promoted the EAPSI program to my colleagues and graduate students. In doing so, I have helped two students successfully secure the fellowship. I have also returned to Japan for the Molecular Biology Society of Japan annual meeting, and was able to present work related to the system I spent my time on in Japan. Furthermore, I was fortunate to be able to see Prof. Hideaki Nojiri and many of the lab members I spent my summer with during the fellowship.
